articles.headline: Gauging the Worth of a Frequent-Flier Credit Card
articles.snippet: Five questions you should ask yourself as airlines alter their frequent-flier programs, add fees and raise the number of miles you need to get some tickets.
articles.abstract: Five questions you should ask yourself as airlines alter their frequent-flier programs, add fees and raise the number of miles you need to get some tickets.
articles.lead_paragraph: One after the other in recent weeks, airlines have altered their frequent-flier mile programs, adding fees, taking away bonuses and raising the number of miles you need for some free tickets.

articles.headline: F.D.I.C. Retirees Ride to Rescue in New Era of Bank Failures
articles.snippet: Facing a growing credit crisis and a rising number of troubled banks, the F.D.I.C. has recruited back many of the people who helped it clean up the savings and loan crisis 20 years ago.
articles.abstract: Facing a growing credit crisis and a rising number of troubled banks, the F.D.I.C. has recruited back many of the people who helped it clean up the savings and loan crisis 20 years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before he retired from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation three years ago, Gary Holloway was cleaning up the remnants of the savings and loan crisis two decades earlier.

articles.headline: Priced Out of Weight Loss Camp
articles.snippet: Although the prevalence of childhood obesity has tripled since 1980, there are few comprehensive or affordable programs to treat them.
articles.abstract: Although the prevalence of childhood obesity has tripled since 1980, there are few comprehensive or affordable programs to treat them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tiffany King has made progress. When the 5-foot-tall 12-year-old arrived at Camp Pocono Trails in June, she weighed 354 pounds. By Sunday’s weigh-in at the weight loss camp, she had lost 37 pounds. She hopes to get down to 304 by the time camp ends next week. Whether she does or not, Tiffany is already one of the lucky few.

articles.headline: Rivals Differ (a Bit) on Financial Market Rules
articles.snippet: Financial scandals and a quarter century of deregulation will give way to new big-government regulation no matter who wins the White House.
articles.abstract: Financial scandals and a quarter century of deregulation will give way to new big-government regulation no matter who wins the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Modernizing the nation’s New Deal-era defenses against financial disaster is not high among the priorities that either Barack Obama or John McCain list for the next president. But events could well plop the issue right in the middle of the winner’s plate.

articles.headline: Some Media Companies Choose to Profit From Pirated YouTube Clips
articles.snippet: After years of regarding pirated video on YouTube as a threat, some major media companies are starting to treat it instead as an advertising opportunity.
articles.abstract: After years of regarding pirated video on YouTube as a threat, some major media companies are starting to treat it instead as an advertising opportunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of regarding pirated video on YouTube as a threat, some major media companies are having a change of heart, treating it instead as an advertising opportunity.

articles.headline: Retire Now, and Risk Falling Short on Your Nest Egg
articles.snippet: If you have just retired or are about to retire, your timing could not be worse.
articles.abstract: If you have just retired or are about to retire, your timing could not be worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you have just retired or are about to retire, your timing could not be worse.

articles.headline: Kremlin Signs Truce but Resists Quick Pullout
articles.snippet: Russia’s president agreed to terms to halt the fighting, but the Kremlin said it would not pull troops out immediately.
articles.abstract: Russia’s president agreed to terms to halt the fighting, but the Kremlin said it would not pull troops out immediately.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  Russia’s president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, on Saturday signed a revised framework for a deal to halt the fighting in neighboring Georgia, which has stirred some of the deepest divisions between world powers since the cold war. But the Kremlin then indicated that despite the accord’s approval, it would not immediately pull its troops from the country.
articles.byline: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY and C.J. CHIVERS

articles.headline: Seeing Tougher Race, Allies Ask Obama to Make ‘Hope’ Specific
articles.snippet: Party leaders, saying the fight against John McCain looks tougher than they imagined, want Barack Obama to do more to address the economic anxieties of voters.
articles.abstract: Party leaders, saying the fight against John McCain looks tougher than they imagined, want Barack Obama to do more to address the economic anxieties of voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Senator Barack Obama prepares to accept the Democratic presidential nomination next week, party leaders in battleground states say the fight ahead against Senator John McCain looks tougher than they imagined, with Mr. Obama vulnerable on multiple fronts despite weeks of cross-country and overseas campaigning.

articles.headline: Methadone Rises as a Painkiller With Big Risks
articles.snippet: Once used mainly in addiction treatment, the drug is now more widely prescribed and is a growing cause of deaths.
articles.abstract: Once used mainly in addiction treatment, the drug is now more widely prescribed and is a growing cause of deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: Suffering from excruciating spinal deterioration, Robby Garvin, 24, of South Carolina, tried many painkillers before his doctor prescribed methadone in June 2006, just before Mr. Garvin and his friend Joey Sutton set off for a weekend at an amusement park.
articles.byline: By Erik Eckholm and Olga Pierce

articles.headline: Looking for Swing Votes in the Boardroom
articles.snippet: As both presidential candidates prepare for the party conventions and publicly spar over economic issues and energy policy, they are also trying to win over big business.
articles.abstract: As both presidential candidates prepare for the party conventions and publicly spar over economic issues and energy policy, they are also trying to win over big business.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE guests who sat down for lunch with Senator Barack Obama at the Fairmont Chicago hotel in June weren’t his usual audience. It was also a closed-door affair  no crowds, no reporters, no oratory  and instead of speaking, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee mostly listened. But the nine men and two women dining with him were leaders of companies like Ford, JPMorgan Chase, Aetna and Duke Energy and were used to doing the talking anyway.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: At Least the Airsickness Bags Are Free
articles.snippet: In just a few short months, the airlines have discovered to their glee that their customers are willing to pay for most everything from checked bags to pillows and blankets.
articles.abstract: In just a few short months, the airlines have discovered to their glee that their customers are willing to pay for most everything from checked bags to pillows and blankets.
articles.lead_paragraph: AS far as airlines are concerned, you are no longer just a passenger. You are an opportunity to raise “ancillary revenue.” And when it comes to charging for things that were once free, the sky’s the limit.

articles.headline: Response to 9/11 Offers Outline of McCain Doctrine
articles.snippet: To his admirers, Senator John McCain’s tough response to the attacks of Sept. 11 is at the heart of his appeal.
articles.abstract: To his admirers, Senator John McCain’s tough response to the attacks of Sept. 11 is at the heart of his appeal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain arrived late at his Senate office on the morning of Sept. 11, 2001, just after the first plane hit the World Trade Center. “This is war,” he murmured to his aides. The sound of scrambling fighter planes rattled the windows, sending a tremor of panic through the room.

articles.headline: Seeking a Detour Around Wall Street
articles.snippet: A question about jobs in investment banking and finance in the face of the current downturn.
articles.abstract: A question about jobs in investment banking and finance in the face of the current downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY asked readers to submit questions for the Coaches Roundtable, where we present a career quandary to a panel of career coaches, and I’ve been sorting through the responses ever since.

articles.headline: A Bond Market, Starved for Sunshine
articles.snippet: Nowhere is disclosure more urgent than in the $2.6 trillion municipal securities market, an arena where information is scant.
articles.abstract: Nowhere is disclosure more urgent than in the $2.6 trillion municipal securities market, an arena where information is scant.
articles.lead_paragraph: IF we have learned anything from this unrelenting credit mess, it is that greater disclosure is needed if investors are to regain their trust in the financial system. Nowhere is this disclosure more urgent than in the $2.6 trillion municipal securities market, an arena where information is scant and investors must pay to view the financial filings that issuers do make.

articles.headline: Pledging to Leave Georgia, Russia Tightens Its Grip
articles.snippet: American officials said the Russian military has been moving launchers for short-range ballistic missiles into South Ossetia.
articles.abstract: American officials said the Russian military has been moving launchers for short-range ballistic missiles into South Ossetia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as Russia pledged to begin withdrawing its forces from neighboring Georgia on Monday, American officials said the Russian military had been moving launchers for short-range ballistic missiles into South Ossetia, a step that appeared intended to tighten its hold on the breakaway territory.

articles.headline: The Enquirer: Even Scandal Can Be News
articles.snippet: To those who look at American tabloid culture and say “good riddance,” I say, not so fast.
articles.abstract: To those who look at American tabloid culture and say “good riddance,” I say, not so fast.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was more than a week since the National Enquirer’s coup about John Edwards’s affair had broken into plain view, but David Perel, the tabloid’s editor in chief, seemed to be expecting my call.

articles.headline: Amid Conference Halls and Keynote Speakers, a Rivalry Forms
articles.snippet: TechCrunch50, a new entrant in the technology conference market, has sparked a dispute over the ethics of the convention circuit and the fees charged to participants.
articles.abstract: TechCrunch50, a new entrant in the technology conference market, has sparked a dispute over the ethics of the convention circuit and the fees charged to participants.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  A frequent ritual of Silicon Valley is the money-making gathering known as the technology conference, where investors, entrepreneurs and industry executives come together to strike deals, catch up on trends and engage in some nonvirtual networking.

articles.headline: Like Politics? Broadcast Your View for Only $6
articles.snippet: Saysme.tv didn’t invent the loudmouth, but, as the company’s logo indicates, it sure hopes to sell him a megaphone.
articles.abstract: Saysme.tv didn’t invent the loudmouth, but, as the company’s logo indicates, it sure hopes to sell him a megaphone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Saysme.tv didn’t invent the loudmouth, but, as the company’s logo indicates, it sure hopes to sell him a megaphone.

articles.headline: Television Starts to Court the Young Voter
articles.snippet: With polls showing a surge in primary-season ballots cast by voters under 30, media outlets are out to convert the newly energized voters into viewers.
articles.abstract: With polls showing a surge in primary-season ballots cast by voters under 30, media outlets are out to convert the newly energized voters into viewers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Television networks are assigning reporters to a new beat this election year: people who don’t watch the evening news.

articles.headline: A Surprise Winner at the Olympic Games in Beijing: NBC
articles.snippet: The Olympics has become the hottest event of the summer, drawing an average audience of about 30 million a night on NBC, far beyond the network’s expectations.
articles.abstract: The Olympics has become the hottest event of the summer, drawing an average audience of about 30 million a night on NBC, far beyond the network’s expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a string of disappointing years in prime time, NBC executives had high hopes for a turnaround with the Beijing Olympics; but those hopes were tempered by a string of concerns.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Richard Sandomir

articles.headline: For Convention, Obama’s Image Is All-American
articles.snippet: Democrats face a number of imperatives at their convention, none trickier than making more voters comfortable with Barack Obama’s background.
articles.abstract: Democrats face a number of imperatives at their convention, none trickier than making more voters comfortable with Barack Obama’s background.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  One of the first images prime-time viewers will see of the Democratic National Convention next week is that of Michelle Obama, who will begin the four-day introduction of her husband, and her family, on her terms.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Export Boom Helps Farms, but Not American Factories
articles.snippet: A surge in U.S. commodity exports is a relief in an otherwise bleak economy, but it is an unreliable prop for an industrial power.
articles.abstract: A surge in U.S. commodity exports is a relief in an otherwise bleak economy, but it is an unreliable prop for an industrial power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Exports are the bright spot this year in an otherwise bleak economy. But the world is not suddenly snapping up made-in-America goods like aircraft, machinery and staplers. The great attraction is decidedly low-luster commodities like corn, wheat, ore and scrap metal.

articles.headline: In Musharraf’s Wake, U.S. Faces Political Disarray
articles.snippet: American officials must now deal with an elected coalition in Pakistan that has so far proven unwilling or incapable of confronting the Taliban insurgency.
articles.abstract: American officials must now deal with an elected coalition in Pakistan that has so far proven unwilling or incapable of confronting the Taliban insurgency.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Facing imminent impeachment charges, President Pervez Musharraf announced his resignation on Monday, after months of belated recognition by American officials that he had become a waning asset in the campaign against terrorism.

articles.headline: Game Maker Retracts Bid for a Rival
articles.snippet: Electronic Arts said that it has withdrawn its $2 billion tender offer to purchase its smaller rival, ending a six-month-long hostile takeover bid.
articles.abstract: Electronic Arts said that it has withdrawn its $2 billion tender offer to purchase its smaller rival, ending a six-month-long hostile takeover bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Strauss Zelnick, chairman of the video game maker Take-Two Interactive, was on a luxury camping vacation in British Columbia when he was interrupted by an unexpected call on Friday.
